Basically, a compiler has multiple stages.
We take the source code.
We process the source code into some internal representation.
We do a lot of different analysis on that representation.
Once we are happy with the code that it is sound,
that it works, we are generating some kind of a next stage.
In the first version of the compiler,
this generation was directly into EVM.
In the current stage, we still have this,
but we also have a second pipeline,
where instead of directly generating to EVM,
we generate to you, which is our intermediate language.
But you must be familiar with you
because it is in line assembly, basically.
And then we take you and generate EVM bytecode.
So that is the pipeline.
And then these are the different libraries
we have in the compiler itself.
So this one is just really tiny helpers.
Yeah, I'm going to move to the other side.
So these are just helpers used by the others.
The assembler is kind of separate.
It's standalone.
It takes in a data structure, like a representation

It generates EVM bytecode, but it also

Then we have this separate helper for language utilities,
but it's really just helpers for the parsers,
because we have two different parsers.
We have the solidarity parser and the ule.
So length UTS is used by both of these.

has another kind of optimizer.
And the libsolidity is a big one.
It's a monster.
It is a solidity parser.
Does all the analysis I mentioned,
and does these two different pipelines for code generation.
And then we have two smaller libraries.
The SMT library is just for the SMD subsystem.
But I think that is also split up.
So some of it is here.
Some of it is in the libsolidity directory.
And lastly, the smallest one is libsolc,
which is a tiny binding that is the only library which
is C, has a C API.
Everything else is C++.
So this basically is a wrapper between C and C++.

and into JavaScript if you happen to use any kind of web

And there's a few issues and maybe some benefits as well.

be super well separated conceptually
or even like interface-wise.

all of this is C++, which is kind of hard to integrate

It is hard to integrate with JavaScript.

You need a C layer as well.

it is not really stable.
If you want to integrate this into Go, it's the same case.
All of the languages, they only work with C.
They don't work with C++.

We want to have clean interfaces between them,

and parallel to this, we could start working on components

it's used by Fay, actually.

U libraries in Rust, which is also used by Fay.

The first useful step could be rewriting the assembler.

The parser itself has me mostly rewritten,

Think the type system that is also kind of old,
